demonstrate that the proposed multimodal approach improves objective realness
prediction performance and produces dense realness maps that effectively
distinguish between realistic and unrealistic spatial regions.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a framework for measuring AI image realness and spotting errors using vision-language models.
AI.motivation: Enhance the practical use and photorealism of AI-generated images by addressing the need for consistent realness and identifying flaws.
AI.method: Utilizes vision-language models trained on large datasets to both assess overall image realness and pinpoint visual inconsistencies.
AI.result: Demonstrates improved realness prediction and provides detailed maps highlighting unrealistic regions.
AI.conclusion: The framework is effective in assessing and improving the realness of AI-generated images, aiding both evaluation and feedback during training.

title: Exact alternative optima for nonlinear optimization problems defined with maximum component objective function constrained by the Sugeno-Weber fuzzy relational inequalities
comment:
9 pages, 1 numerical example, presented at 17th International
  Conference on Information Technology, Computer and Telecommunication (ITCTC),
  Poland, December 2022
summary:
In this paper, we study a latticized optimization problem with fuzzy
relational inequality constraints where the feasible region is formed as the
intersection of two inequality fuzzy systems and Sugeno-Weber family of t-norms
is considered as fuzzy composition. Sugeno-Weber family of t-norms and
t-conorms is one of the most applied one in various fuzzy modelling problems.
This family of t-norms and t-conorms was suggested by Weber for modeling
intersection and union of fuzzy sets. Also, the t-conorms were suggested as
addition rules by Sugeno for so-called alpha-fuzzy measures. The resolution of
the feasible region of the problem is firstly investigated when it is defined
with max-Sugeno-Weber composition and a necessary and sufficient condition is
presented for determining the feasibility. Then, based on some theoretical
properties of the problem, an algorithm is presented for solving this nonlinear
problem. It is proved that the algorithm can find the exact optimal solution
and an example is presented to illustrate the proposed algorithm.

AI.tldr: This paper examines an optimization problem constrained by fuzzy relational inequalities using Sugeno-Weber t-norms, proposing an algorithm that guarantees an exact solution.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of solving optimization problems constrained by fuzzy relational inequalities effectively and to utilize the powerful Sugeno-Weber family of t-norms/t-conorms.
AI.method: The paper first examines the feasibility of the problem region under max-Sugeno-Weber composition, provides a necessary and sufficient feasibility condition, and proposes a resolution algorithm based on theoretical properties.
AI.result: The proposed algorithm is proven to attain the exact optimal solution, and its validity is demonstrated through an example.
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully formulates the problem, analyzes its feasibility, and provides a reliable solution algorithm, contributing valuable insights to fuzzy modeling and optimization.

title: Meta-model Neural Process for Probabilistic Power Flow under Varying N-1 System Topologies
comment: An improved version for the conference paper at PESGM 2025
summary:
The probabilistic power flow (PPF) problem is essential to quantifying the
distribution of the nodal voltages due to uncertain injections. The
conventional PPF problem considers a fixed topology, and the solutions to such
a PPF problem are associated with this topology. A change in the topology might
alter the power flow patterns and thus require the PPF problem to be solved
again. The previous PPF model and its solutions are no longer valid for the new
topology. This practice incurs both inconvenience and computation burdens as
more contingencies are foreseen due to high renewables and a large share of
electric vehicles. This paper presents a novel topology-adaptive approach,
based on the meta-model Neural Process (MMNP), for finding the solutions to PPF
problems under varying N-1 topologies, particularly with one-line failures. By
leveraging context set-based topology representation and conditional
distribution over function learning techniques, the proposed MMNP enhances the
robustness of PPF models to topology variations, mitigating the need for
retraining PPF models on a new configuration. Simulations on an IEEE 9-bus
system and IEEE 118-bus system validate the model's performance. The maximum
%L1-relative error norm was observed as 1.11% and 0.77% in 9-bus and 118-bus,
respectively. This adaptive approach fills a critical gap in PPF methodology in
an era of increasing grid volatility.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a novel Neural Process-based model that efficiently solves probabilistic power flow (PPF) problems for variable grid topologies, addressing computational inefficiencies tied to traditional methods.
AI.motivation: To address inefficiencies in existing PPF methods that require re-solving when grid topologies change, especially as grid contingency events increase due to higher renewable energy and electric vehicle integration.
AI.method: Develop a topology-adaptive approach using the meta-model Neural Process (MMNP), which leverages context-set-based topology representation and conditional distribution techniques to learn solutions under varying topologies.
AI.result: The proposed MMNP method achieved a maximum L1-relative error norm of 1.11% on the IEEE 9-bus system and 0.77% on the IEEE 118-bus system, showcasing robust and accurate performance for varying topologies.
AI.conclusion: The topology-adaptive MMNP approach mitigates the computational and modeling limitations of traditional PPF methods, offering an efficient solution for grids experiencing frequent topology changes.

title: StyleSculptor: Zero-Shot Style-Controllable 3D Asset Generation with Texture-Geometry Dual Guidance
summary:
Creating 3D assets that follow the texture and geometry style of existing
ones is often desirable or even inevitable in practical applications like video
gaming and virtual reality. While impressive progress has been made in
generating 3D objects from text or images, creating style-controllable 3D
assets remains a complex and challenging problem. In this work, we propose
StyleSculptor, a novel training-free approach for generating style-guided 3D
assets from a content image and one or more style images. Unlike previous
works, StyleSculptor achieves style-guided 3D generation in a zero-shot manner,
enabling fine-grained 3D style control that captures the texture, geometry, or
both styles of user-provided style images. At the core of StyleSculptor is a
novel Style Disentangled Attention (SD-Attn) module, which establishes a
dynamic interaction between the input content image and style image for
style-guided 3D asset generation via a cross-3D attention mechanism, enabling
stable feature fusion and effective style-guided generation. To alleviate
semantic content leakage, we also introduce a style-disentangled feature
selection strategy within the SD-Attn module, which leverages the variance of
3D feature patches to disentangle style- and content-significant channels,
allowing selective feature injection within the attention framework. With
SD-Attn, the network can dynamically compute texture-, geometry-, or
both-guided features to steer the 3D generation process. Built upon this, we
further propose the Style Guided Control (SGC) mechanism, which enables
exclusive geometry- or texture-only stylization, as well as adjustable style
intensity control. Extensive experiments demonstrate that StyleSculptor
outperforms existing baseline methods in producing high-fidelity 3D assets.

AI.tldr: StyleSculptor introduces a training-free method for generating 3D assets in a user-defined style, enabling precise texture and geometry control without prior training.
AI.motivation: The motivation behind the paper is to address the challenge of creating 3D assets with controllable styles to match specific texture and geometric patterns of existing designs, particularly useful in gaming and virtual reality applications.
AI.method: The proposed method integrates a Style Disentangled Attention (SD-Attn) module for dynamic cross-3D attention and feature fusion combined with a Style Guided Control (SGC) mechanism for exclusive texture or geometry stylization and adjustable style intensity.
AI.result: StyleSculptor demonstrates superior performance over existing methods in generating high-fidelity 3D assets that accurately adapt style provided by the user in terms of both geometry and texture.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that StyleSculptor successfully achieves style-guided 3D asset creation in a zero-shot manner, offering practical tools for precise and customizable 3D generation without requiring pre-training.

title: 3D Aware Region Prompted Vision Language Model
summary:
We present Spatial Region 3D (SR-3D) aware vision-language model that
connects single-view 2D images and multi-view 3D data through a shared visual
token space. SR-3D supports flexible region prompting, allowing users to
annotate regions with bounding boxes, segmentation masks on any frame, or
directly in 3D, without the need for exhaustive multi-frame labeling. We
achieve this by enriching 2D visual features with 3D positional embeddings,
which allows the 3D model to draw upon strong 2D priors for more accurate
spatial reasoning across frames, even when objects of interest do not co-occur
within the same view. Extensive experiments on both general 2D vision language
and specialized 3D spatial benchmarks demonstrate that SR-3D achieves
state-of-the-art performance, underscoring its effectiveness for unifying 2D
and 3D representation space on scene understanding. Moreover, we observe
applicability to in-the-wild videos without sensory 3D inputs or ground-truth
3D annotations, where SR-3D accurately infers spatial relationships and metric
measurements.

AI.tldr: SR-3D introduces a model that integrates 2D images and multi-view 3D data for improved spatial understanding through a shared token space.
AI.motivation: To bridge the gap between 2D visual data and 3D spatial reasoning, enabling enhanced 3D scene understanding using 2D priors.
AI.method: Enriching 2D visual features with 3D positional embeddings, and allowing flexible region prompting with bounding boxes, segmentation masks, or direct 3D annotations.
AI.result: SR-3D achieves state-of-the-art results on both general 2D vision-language and specialized 3D benchmarks, showing strong spatial reasoning across frames.
AI.conclusion: SR-3D effectively unifies 2D and 3D representations, demonstrating its utility for scene understanding and real-world applications, even without ground-truth 3D data.

title: Enhancing Radiographic Disease Detection with MetaCheX, a Context-Aware Multimodal Model
comment: All authors contributed equally, 5 pages, 2 figures, 1 table
summary:
Existing deep learning models for chest radiology often neglect patient
metadata, limiting diagnostic accuracy and fairness. To bridge this gap, we
introduce MetaCheX, a novel multimodal framework that integrates chest X-ray
images with structured patient metadata to replicate clinical decision-making.
Our approach combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) backbone with
metadata processed by a multilayer perceptron through a shared classifier.
Evaluated on the CheXpert Plus dataset, MetaCheX consistently outperformed
radiograph-only baseline models across multiple CNN architectures. By
integrating metadata, the overall diagnostic accuracy was significantly
improved, measured by an increase in AUROC. The results of this study
demonstrate that metadata reduces algorithmic bias and enhances model
generalizability across diverse patient populations. MetaCheX advances clinical
artificial intelligence toward robust, context-aware radiographic disease
detection.

AI.tldr: MetaCheX is a framework that combines chest X-rays and patient metadata to improve diagnostic accuracy and fairness in radiology.
AI.motivation: Existing methods in chest radiology often ignore patient metadata, which hampers diagnostic accuracy and fairness.
AI.method: MetaCheX integrates chest X-ray imaging via a CNN with patient metadata processed through a multilayer perceptron, using a shared classifier.
AI.result: MetaCheX outperformed radiograph-only baselines in diagnostic accuracy on the CheXpert Plus dataset, as evidenced by an increased AUROC.
AI.conclusion: The integration of metadata improves diagnostic accuracy, reduces algorithmic bias, and enhances model performance across diverse patient groups, making MetaCheX a step forward in clinical AI.

title: More Similar than Dissimilar: Modeling Annotators for Cross-Corpus Speech Emotion Recognition
comment:
\copyright 20XX IEEE. Personal use of this material is permitted.
  Permission from IEEE must be obtained for all other uses, in any current or
  future media, including reprinting/republishing this material for advertising
  or promotional purposes, creating new collective works, for resale or
  redistribution to servers or lists, or reuse of any copyrighted component of
  this work in other works
summary:
Speech emotion recognition systems often predict a consensus value generated
from the ratings of multiple annotators. However, these models have limited
ability to predict the annotation of any one person. Alternatively, models can
learn to predict the annotations of all annotators. Adapting such models to new
annotators is difficult as new annotators must individually provide sufficient
labeled training data. We propose to leverage inter-annotator similarity by
using a model pre-trained on a large annotator population to identify a
similar, previously seen annotator. Given a new, previously unseen, annotator
and limited enrollment data, we can make predictions for a similar annotator,
enabling off-the-shelf annotation of unseen data in target datasets, providing
a mechanism for extremely low-cost personalization. We demonstrate our approach
significantly outperforms other off-the-shelf approaches, paving the way for
lightweight emotion adaptation, practical for real-world deployment.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a method to efficiently personalize speech emotion recognition by leveraging inter-annotator similarity, requiring minimal data from new annotators.
AI.motivation: Current speech emotion recognition models struggle to predict individual annotator preferences and need extensive data to adapt to new annotators.
AI.method: The proposed system identifies a similar annotator from a pre-trained model on a large population, enabling predictions for a new annotator using limited data.
AI.result: The approach significantly outperforms other off-the-shelf methods in personalization and lightweight adaptation.
AI.conclusion: The system offers a practical, low-cost solution for adapting emotion recognition in real-world scenarios by leveraging annotator similarity.

title: Joint AoI and Handover Optimization in Space-Air-Ground Integrated Network
summary:
Despite the widespread deployment of terrestrial networks, providing reliable
communication services to remote areas and maintaining connectivity during
emergencies remains challenging. Low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite constellations
offer promising solutions with their global coverage capabilities and reduced
latency, yet struggle with intermittent coverage and limited communication
windows due to orbital dynamics. This paper introduces an age of information
(AoI)-aware space-air-ground integrated network (SAGIN) architecture that
leverages a high-altitude platform (HAP) as intelligent relay between the LEO
satellites and ground terminals. Our three-layer design employs hybrid
free-space optical (FSO) links for high-capacity satellite-to-HAP communication
and reliable radio frequency (RF) links for HAP-to-ground transmission, and
thus addressing the temporal discontinuity in LEO satellite coverage while
serving diverse user priorities. Specifically, we formulate a joint
optimization problem to simultaneously minimize the AoI and satellite handover
frequency through optimal transmit power distribution and satellite selection
decisions. This highly dynamic, non-convex problem with time-coupled
constraints presents significant computational challenges for traditional
approaches. To address these difficulties, we propose a novel diffusion model
(DM)-enhanced dueling double deep Q-network with action decomposition and state
transformer encoder (DD3QN-AS) algorithm that incorporates transformer-based
temporal feature extraction and employs a DM-based latent prompt generative
module to refine state-action representations through conditional denoising.
Simulation results highlight the superior performance of the proposed approach
compared with policy-based methods and some other deep reinforcement learning
(DRL) benchmarks.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes an AoI-aware space-air-ground integrated network (SAGIN) architecture utilizing high-altitude platforms (HAPs) as intelligent relays between LEO satellites and ground terminals, aiming to improve coverage, reduce latency, and optimize communication dynamics.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to address challenges in remote area communication and emergency connectivity caused by the intermittent coverage and limited communication windows of LEO satellites.
AI.method: The study formulates a joint optimization problem to minimize the AoI and satellite handover frequency. They introduce a DD3QN-AS algorithm enhanced with diffusion models and state transformer encoders.
AI.result: Simulation results demonstrate superior performance of the proposed algorithm compared to policy-based methods and alternative DRL benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: The proposed architecture and algorithm fulfill the dual goals of improving communication reliability across remote areas and optimizing satellite operations in SAGINs.

title: VADER: A Variational Autoencoder to Infer Planetary Masses and Gas-Dust Disk Properties Around Young Stars
comment:
6 pages, 5 figures, Accepted and Published at International
  Conference on Machine Learning, Machine Learning for Astrophysics Workshop
  2025
summary:
We present \textbf{VADER} (Variational Autoencoder for Disks Embedded with
Rings), for inferring both planet mass and global disk properties from
high-resolution ALMA dust continuum images of protoplanetary disks (PPDs).
VADER, a probabilistic deep learning model, enables uncertainty-aware inference
of planet masses, $\alpha$-viscosity, dust-to-gas ratio, Stokes number, flaring
index, and the number of planets directly from protoplanetary disk images.
VADER is trained on over 100{,}000 synthetic images of PPDs generated from
\texttt{FARGO3D} simulations post-processed with \texttt{RADMC3D}. Our trained
model predicts physical planet and disk parameters with $R^2 > 0.9$ from dust
continuum images of PPDs. Applied to 23 real disks, VADER's mass estimates are
consistent with literature values and reveal latent correlations that reflect
known disk physics. Our results establish VAE-based generative models as robust
tools for probabilistic astrophysical inference, with direct applications to
interpreting protoplanetary disk substructures in the era of large
interferometric surveys.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces VADER, a probabilistic deep learning model using a variational autoencoder, to infer planetary mass and disk properties from high-resolution protoplanetary disk images. It delivers highly accurate and uncertainty-aware predictions.
AI.motivation: To develop a robust method for extracting global disk properties and planet mass from high-resolution images of protoplanetary disks, addressing the need for precise, data-intensive astrophysical tools.
AI.method: Utilized a variational autoencoder (VAE) trained on over 100,000 synthetic PPD images simulated via FARGO3D and post-processed with RADMC3D. The model incorporated probabilistic learning for uncertainty-aware predictions.
AI.result: VADER demonstrated prediction accuracies with $R^2 > 0.9$ on physical parameters and its estimations on real disks align well with extant literature. It also uncovered latent physical correlations in disk data.
AI.conclusion: The study establishes the utility of VADER as a robust and interpretable tool for astrophysical inference in PPD images, with strong implications for use in large-scale interferometric surveys.

title: Universal Gröbner Bases of (Universal) Multiview Ideals
summary:
Multiview ideals arise from the geometry of image formation in pinhole
cameras, and universal multiview ideals are their analogs for unknown cameras.
We prove that a natural collection of polynomials form a universal Gr\"obner
basis for both types of ideals using a criterion introduced by Huang and
Larson, and include a proof of their criterion in our setting. Symmetry
reduction and induction enable the method to be deployed on an infinite family
of ideals. We also give an explicit description of the matroids on which the
methodology depends, in the context of multiview ideals.

AI.tldr: The paper deals with multiview ideals and their universal variants, providing proofs for their universal Gröbner basis representation and utilizing symmetry reduction for infinite families.
AI.motivation: To explore the algebraic and geometric properties of multiview ideals formed in pinhole camera image formation and extend those to unknown cameras.
AI.method: The authors use a criterion by Huang and Larson to prove a universal Gröbner basis for multiview ideals, deploying symmetry reduction and induction for generalization.
AI.result: The method successfully proves the universal Gröbner basis for multiview ideals, gives a proof of the Huang-Larson criterion, and describes associated matroids.
AI.conclusion: The paper advances the understanding of multiview ideals and their universal counterparts, offering tools for handling their algebraic structure and extending insights using generalizable methods.

title: Structured Information Loss in Network Embeddings
summary:
We analyze a simple algorithm for network embedding, explicitly
characterizing conditions under which the learned representation encodes the
graph's generative model fully, partially, or not at all. In cases where the
embedding loses some information (i.e., is not invertible), we describe the
equivalence classes of graphons that map to the same embedding, finding that
these classes preserve community structure but lose substantial density
information. Finally, we show implications for community detection and link
prediction. Our results suggest strong limitations on the effectiveness of link
prediction based on embeddings alone, and we show common conditions under which
naive link prediction adds edges in a disproportionate manner that can either
mitigate or exacerbate structural biases.

AI.tldr: The paper studies the limitations and implications of a network embedding algorithm concerning the representation of generative graph models and its applications in link prediction and community detection.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to understand the effectiveness and limitations of network embedding algorithms in preserving graph generative models and their impact on structural biases in link prediction and community detection.
AI.method: The authors explicitly characterize when embeddings capture graph generative models, analyze equivalence classes of graphons, and assess the effects of embeddings on downstream tasks like link prediction.
AI.result: Findings reveal that embeddings preserve community structure but lose density information. Link prediction using embeddings alone is prone to structural biases, sometimes mitigating or exacerbating them.
AI.conclusion: Network embeddings have limitations in fully representing generative graph models, which affects tasks like link prediction. Awareness of these biases can guide better methods or algorithms in similar applications.

title: MEGAN: Mixture of Experts for Robust Uncertainty Estimation in Endoscopy Videos
comment: 11 pages, 2 figures, 1 table, accepted at UNSURE, MICCAI
summary:
Reliable uncertainty quantification (UQ) is essential in medical AI.
Evidential Deep Learning (EDL) offers a computationally efficient way to
quantify model uncertainty alongside predictions, unlike traditional methods
such as Monte Carlo (MC) Dropout and Deep Ensembles (DE). However, all these
methods often rely on a single expert's annotations as ground truth for model
training, overlooking the inter-rater variability in healthcare. To address
this issue, we propose MEGAN, a Multi-Expert Gating Network that aggregates
uncertainty estimates and predictions from multiple AI experts via EDL models
trained with diverse ground truths and modeling strategies. MEGAN's gating
network optimally combines predictions and uncertainties from each EDL model,
enhancing overall prediction confidence and calibration. We extensively
benchmark MEGAN on endoscopy videos for Ulcerative colitis (UC) disease
severity estimation, assessed by visual labeling of Mayo Endoscopic Subscore
(MES), where inter-rater variability is prevalent. In large-scale prospective
UC clinical trial, MEGAN achieved a 3.5% improvement in F1-score and a 30.5%
reduction in Expected Calibration Error (ECE) compared to existing methods.
Furthermore, MEGAN facilitated uncertainty-guided sample stratification,
reducing the annotation burden and potentially increasing efficiency and
consistency in UC trials.

AI.tldr: MEGAN, a Multi-Expert Gating Network, improves uncertainty quantification in medical AI by aggregating predictions and uncertainties from multiple Evidential Deep Learning models and demonstrates enhanced performance on Ulcerative Colitis severity estimation.
AI.motivation: Traditional uncertainty quantification methods often rely on a single expert's annotations, neglecting inter-rater variability, which is critical in healthcare applications.
AI.method: MEGAN uses multiple EDL models trained with diverse ground truths, combining their predictions and uncertainties through a gating network to enhance calibration and prediction reliability.
AI.result: MEGAN achieved a 3.5% improvement in F1-score and a 30.5% reduction in Expected Calibration Error in a large-scale UC clinical trial.
AI.conclusion: MEGAN not only improves prediction confidence and calibration but also facilitates efficient and consistent clinical processes by supporting uncertainty-guided sample stratification.

title: SamudrACE: Fast and Accurate Coupled Climate Modeling with 3D Ocean and Atmosphere Emulators
summary:
Traditional numerical global climate models simulate the full Earth system by
exchanging boundary conditions between separate simulators of the atmosphere,
ocean, sea ice, land surface, and other geophysical processes. This paradigm
allows for distributed development of individual components within a common
framework, unified by a coupler that handles translation between realms via
spatial or temporal alignment and flux exchange. Following a similar approach
adapted for machine learning-based emulators, we present SamudrACE: a coupled
global climate model emulator which produces centuries-long simulations at
1-degree horizontal, 6-hourly atmospheric, and 5-daily oceanic resolution, with
145 2D fields spanning 8 atmospheric and 19 oceanic vertical levels, plus sea
ice, surface, and top-of-atmosphere variables. SamudrACE is highly stable and
has low climate biases comparable to those of its components with prescribed
boundary forcing, with realistic variability in coupled climate phenomena such
as ENSO that is not possible to simulate in uncoupled mode.

AI.tldr: SamudrACE is a coupled global climate model emulator providing long-term, high-resolution simulations while maintaining low climate biases and realistic variability.
AI.motivation: To advance climate modeling by leveraging machine learning, ensuring stability and realistic climate variability for coupled phenomena like ENSO.
AI.method: Machine learning-based emulation of individual Earth system components, coupled through spatial and temporal boundary alignment.
AI.result: SamudrACE delivers centuries-long simulations with 1-degree horizontal and high temporal resolution, producing realistic coupled climate patterns and low biases.
AI.conclusion: SamudrACE is an effective tool for simulating complex climate interactions, benefiting researchers and complementing traditional models.

title: Generalizable Holographic Reconstruction via Amplitude-Only Diffusion Priors
comment:
Keywords: Diffusion model, phase retrieval, inline-holography,
  inverse problem
summary:
Phase retrieval in inline holography is a fundamental yet ill-posed inverse
problem due to the nonlinear coupling between amplitude and phase in coherent
imaging. We present a novel off-the-shelf solution that leverages a diffusion
model trained solely on object amplitude to recover both amplitude and phase
from diffraction intensities. Using a predictor-corrector sampling framework
with separate likelihood gradients for amplitude and phase, our method enables
complex field reconstruction without requiring ground-truth phase data for
training. We validate the proposed approach through extensive simulations and
experiments, demonstrating robust generalization across diverse object shapes,
imaging system configurations, and modalities, including lensless setups.
Notably, a diffusion prior trained on simple amplitude data (e.g., polystyrene
beads) successfully reconstructs complex biological tissue structures,
highlighting the method's adaptability. This framework provides a
cost-effective, generalizable solution for nonlinear inverse problems in
computational imaging, and establishes a foundation for broader coherent
imaging applications beyond holography.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a novel method for phase retrieval in inline holography using a diffusion model trained on amplitude data, enabling complex field reconstruction without needing ground-truth phase data.
AI.motivation: Phase retrieval is an ill-posed problem due to the nonlinear relation between amplitude and phase in coherent imaging, necessitating efficient solutions.
AI.method: The proposed method uses a diffusion model trained on object amplitude and a predictor-corrector sampling framework with likelihood gradients for amplitude and phase, enabling phase retrieval without ground-truth phase data.
AI.result: The method demonstrates robust generalization across various objects, imaging systems, and modalities, including accurate reconstruction of complex biological tissues using data from simple objects like polystyrene beads.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers a general, cost-effective solution for nonlinear inverse problems in computational imaging and sets the stage for applications beyond holography.

title: Gesture Evaluation in Virtual Reality
comment:
Published in Proceedings of the 26th International Conference on
  Multimodal Interaction (ICMI '24), ACM. Copyright 2024 ACM. Licensed under CC
  BY
summary:
Gestures are central to human communication, enriching interactions through
non-verbal expression. Virtual avatars increasingly use AI-generated gestures
to enhance life-likeness, yet evaluations have largely been confined to 2D.
Virtual Reality (VR) provides an immersive alternative that may affect how
gestures are perceived. This paper presents a comparative evaluation of
computer-generated gestures in VR and 2D, examining three models from the 2023
GENEA Challenge. Results show that gestures viewed in VR were rated slightly
higher on average, with the strongest effect observed for motion-capture "true
movement." While model rankings remained consistent across settings, VR
influenced participants' overall perception and offered unique benefits over
traditional 2D evaluation.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates computer-generated gestures in both VR and 2D settings, showing that VR slightly enhances perception, particularly with motion-capture gestures.
AI.motivation: To explore how immersive virtual reality influences the perception of AI-generated gestures compared to traditional 2D space.
AI.method: A comparative evaluation of three models from the 2023 GENEA Challenge was conducted, within both VR and 2D environments.
AI.result: Gestures in VR were rated slightly higher on average, especially motion-capture gestures, while model rankings stayed consistent across formats.
AI.conclusion: VR enhances the perception of AI-generated gestures and provides unique advantages over traditional 2D evaluation.

title: A Pressure-Based Diffusion Model for Influence Maximization on Social Networks
summary:
In many real-world scenarios, an individual's local social network carries
significant influence over the opinions they form and subsequently propagate to
others. In this paper, we propose a novel diffusion model -- the Pressure
Threshold model (PT) -- for dynamically simulating the spread of influence
through a social network. This new model extends the popular Linear Threshold
Model (LT) by adjusting a node's outgoing influence proportional to the
influence it receives from its activated neighbors. We address the Influence
Maximization (IM) problem, which involves selecting the most effective seed
nodes to achieve maximal graph coverage after a diffusion process, and how the
problem manifests with the PT Model. Experiments conducted on real-world
networks, facilitated by enhancements to the open-source network-diffusion
Python library, CyNetDiff, demonstrate unique seed node selection for the PT
Model when compared to the LT Model. Moreover, analyses demonstrate that
densely connected networks amplify pressure effects more significantly than
sparse networks.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the Pressure Threshold model (PT) to simulate influence spread in social networks, modifies the Linear Threshold model, and studies seed node selection for Influence Maximization (IM).
AI.motivation: To address limitations in existing diffusion models like the Linear Threshold model, specifically by incorporating dynamic influence adjustments based on incoming pressure.
AI.method: Developed the PT model where a node's outgoing influence adjusts dynamically based on its activated neighbors' influence. Used experiments on real-world networks with enhanced open-source tools.
AI.result: The PT model demonstrated unique and distinct seed node selection compared to the LT model. It also showed increased influence propagation in densely connected networks.
AI.conclusion: The PT model effectively simulates social influence spread and impacts Influence Maximization strategies, especially in dense networks.

title: A Lightweight Pipeline for Noisy Speech Voice Cloning and Accurate Lip Sync Synthesis
summary:
Recent developments in voice cloning and talking head generation demonstrate
impressive capabilities in synthesizing natural speech and realistic lip
synchronization. Current methods typically require and are trained on large
scale datasets and computationally intensive processes using clean studio
recorded inputs that is infeasible in noisy or low resource environments. In
this paper, we introduce a new modular pipeline comprising Tortoise text to
speech. It is a transformer based latent diffusion model that can perform high
fidelity zero shot voice cloning given only a few training samples. We use a
lightweight generative adversarial network architecture for robust real time
lip synchronization. The solution will contribute to many essential tasks
concerning less reliance on massive pre training generation of emotionally
expressive speech and lip synchronization in noisy and unconstrained scenarios.
The modular structure of the pipeline allows an easy extension for future multi
modal and text guided voice modulation and it could be used in real world
systems.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a modular pipeline combining Tortoise text-to-speech and GAN-based lip synchronization for zero-shot voice cloning and real-time lip-sync in noisy environments.
AI.motivation: Current methods for voice cloning and lip synchronization rely on extensive datasets, clean input conditions, and significant computational resources, making them impractical for noisy or low-resource environments.
AI.method: The authors propose a modular pipeline using Tortoise text-to-speech (a transformer-based latent diffusion model for zero-shot voice cloning) alongside a lightweight GAN for real-time lip synchronization.
AI.result: The pipeline achieves high-quality voice cloning and robust lip synchronization under noisy and unconstrained conditions, requiring minimal training samples.
AI.conclusion: This modular approach reduces dependence on massive pre-training and enables emotionally expressive speech synthesis and lip sync in challenging scenarios, with scalability for future multimodal applications.

title: Sustainable LSTM-Based Precoding for RIS-Aided mmWave MIMO Systems with Implicit CSI
comment:
6 pages, 5 figures, 2 tables, and accepted by 2025 IEEE Globecom
  Workshops
summary:
In this paper, we propose a sustainable long short-term memory (LSTM)-based
precoding framework for reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted
millimeter-wave (mmWave) MIMO systems. Instead of explicit channel state
information (CSI) estimation, the framework exploits uplink pilot sequences to
implicitly learn channel characteristics, reducing both pilot overhead and
inference complexity. Practical hardware constraints are addressed by
incorporating the phase-dependent amplitude model of RIS elements, while a
multi-label training strategy improves robustness when multiple near-optimal
codewords yield comparable performance. Simulations show that the proposed
design achieves over 90% of the spectral efficiency of exhaustive search (ES)
with only 2.2% of its computation time, cutting energy consumption by nearly
two orders of magnitude. The method also demonstrates resilience under
distribution mismatch and scalability to larger RIS arrays, making it a
practical and energy-efficient solution for sustainable 6G wireless networks.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a sustainable LSTM-based precoding framework for RIS-assisted mmWave MIMO that implicitly learns channel characteristics for efficiency.
AI.motivation: To address challenges in mmWave MIMO systems such as high pilot overhead, inference complexity, and energy consumption while accommodating practical hardware constraints.
AI.method: The framework uses LSTM models that exploit uplink pilot sequences, incorporating RIS phase-dependent amplitude modeling and multi-label training for robustness.
AI.result: The design achieves over 90% spectral efficiency of exhaustive search with only 2.2% computation time, reducing energy consumption significantly.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach is energy-efficient, scalable, and robust, making it highly practical for next-generation sustainable 6G networks.

title: Improving Anomalous Sound Detection with Attribute-aware Representation from Domain-adaptive Pre-training
summary:
Anomalous Sound Detection (ASD) is often formulated as a machine attribute
classification task, a strategy necessitated by the common scenario where only
normal data is available for training. However, the exhaustive collection of
machine attribute labels is laborious and impractical. To address the challenge
of missing attribute labels, this paper proposes an agglomerative hierarchical
clustering method for the assignment of pseudo-attribute labels using
representations derived from a domain-adaptive pre-trained model, which are
expected to capture machine attribute characteristics. We then apply model
adaptation to this pre-trained model through supervised fine-tuning for machine
attribute classification, resulting in a new state-of-the-art performance.
Evaluation on the Detection and Classification of Acoustic Scenes and Events
(DCASE) 2025 Challenge dataset demonstrates that our proposed approach yields
significant performance gains, ultimately outperforming our previous
top-ranking system in the challenge.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an agglomerative hierarchical clustering approach to assign pseudo-attribute labels for anomalous sound detection (ASD), leveraging representations from a domain-adaptive pre-trained model, followed by fine-tuning for enhanced classification accuracy.
AI.motivation: The limited availability of labeled machine attribute data for ASD makes exhaustive label collection impractical, motivating the need for a method that can assign pseudo-attribute labels using readily accessible representations.
AI.method: The authors employ a domain-adaptive pre-trained model to extract representations and assign pseudo-attribute labels through agglomerative hierarchical clustering. They then adapt the model further with supervised fine-tuning for machine attribute classification.
AI.result: The proposed approach achieves substantial performance improvements in ASD, surpassing the authors' previously top-ranking model on the DCASE 2025 Challenge dataset.
AI.conclusion: The method successfully addresses the issue of missing attribute labels, achieving state-of-the-art performance and demonstrating its efficacy in ASD tasks.

title: QDFlow: A Python package for physics simulations of quantum dot devices
summary:
Recent advances in machine learning (ML) have accelerated progress in
calibrating and operating quantum dot (QD) devices. However, most ML approaches
rely on access to large, high-quality labeled datasets for training,
benchmarking, and validation, with labels capturing key features in the data.
Obtaining such datasets experimentally is challenging due to limited data
availability and the labor-intensive nature of labeling. QDFlow is an
open-source physics simulator for multi-QD arrays that generates realistic
synthetic data with ground-truth labels. QDFlow combines a self-consistent
Thomas-Fermi solver, a dynamic capacitance model, and flexible noise modules to
produce charge stability diagrams and ray-based data closely resembling
experiments. With extensive tunable parameters and customizable noise models,
QDFlow supports the creation of large, diverse datasets for ML development,
benchmarking, and quantum device research.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces QDFlow, an open-source physics simulator for generating synthetic data with ground-truth labels for quantum dot arrays.
AI.motivation: Machine learning approaches for quantum dot devices require labeled datasets, which are difficult to obtain experimentally due to labor-intensive labeling and data limitations.
AI.method: QDFlow integrates a self-consistent Thomas-Fermi solver, a dynamic capacitance model, and noise modules to simulate charge stability diagrams and ray-based data.
AI.result: QDFlow produces realistic synthetic datasets resembling experimental results and supports customizable noise models and extensive tunable parameters.
AI.conclusion: QDFlow is a practical tool for accelerated ML development, benchmarking, and quantum dot device research through synthetic data generation.

title: DeltaHedge: A Multi-Agent Framework for Portfolio Options Optimization
comment:
Presented at Pacific Asia Conference on Information Systems (PACIS
  2025), Kuala Lumpur. Official proceedings available at
  https://aisel.aisnet.org/pacis2025/aiandml/aiandml/25/. 16 pages, 7 figures,
  3 tables
summary:
In volatile financial markets, balancing risk and return remains a
significant challenge. Traditional approaches often focus solely on equity
allocation, overlooking the strategic advantages of options trading for dynamic
risk hedging. This work presents DeltaHedge, a multi-agent framework that
integrates options trading with AI-driven portfolio management. By combining
advanced reinforcement learning techniques with an ensembled options-based
hedging strategy, DeltaHedge enhances risk-adjusted returns and stabilizes
portfolio performance across varying market conditions. Experimental results
demonstrate that DeltaHedge outperforms traditional strategies and standalone
models, underscoring its potential to transform practical portfolio management
in complex financial environments. Building on these findings, this paper
contributes to the fields of quantitative finance and AI-driven portfolio
optimization by introducing a novel multi-agent system for integrating options
trading strategies, addressing a gap in the existing literature.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces DeltaHedge, an AI-driven multi-agent system combining options trading and portfolio management for better risk-adjusted returns and stability in volatile markets.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the challenge of balancing risk and return in volatile financial markets, and overcoming the limitations of traditional equity-focused portfolio strategies by incorporating options trading.
AI.method: The authors utilize an AI-driven multi-agent framework called DeltaHedge, leveraging reinforcement learning integrated with ensembled options-based hedging strategies to dynamically manage portfolios in varying market conditions.
AI.result: The experimental results indicate that DeltaHedge outperforms traditional portfolio strategies and standalone models, achieving superior risk-adjusted returns and enhanced portfolio stability.
AI.conclusion: This work introduces a groundbreaking multi-agent system that bridges AI and options trading, advancing the fields of quantitative finance and portfolio optimization, and showcasing its transformative potential in complex financial management.

title: A Graph-Based Approach to Alert Contextualisation in Security Operations Centres
summary:
Interpreting the massive volume of security alerts is a significant challenge
in Security Operations Centres (SOCs). Effective contextualisation is
important, enabling quick distinction between genuine threats and benign
activity to prioritise what needs further analysis.This paper proposes a
graph-based approach to enhance alert contextualisation in a SOC by aggregating
alerts into graph-based alert groups, where nodes represent alerts and edges
denote relationships within defined time-windows. By grouping related alerts,
we enable analysis at a higher abstraction level, capturing attack steps more
effectively than individual alerts. Furthermore, to show that our format is
well suited for downstream machine learning methods, we employ Graph Matching
Networks (GMNs) to correlate incoming alert groups with historical incidents,
providing analysts with additional insights.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a graph-based approach to better contextualize and group alerts in Security Operations Centres (SOCs) for improved handling and analysis.
AI.motivation: Security Operations Centres face challenges in processing and understanding massive volumes of security alerts, often lacking effective means for rapid contextualization to distinguish threats.
AI.method: The paper proposes using graph-based alert groups where nodes are alerts and edges are relationships in time windows. It employs Graph Matching Networks (GMNs) to correlate current alerts with historical incidents.
AI.result: By grouping related alerts, the graph-based approach allows for analysis at higher abstraction levels, effectively capturing attack steps and facilitating machine learning applications.
AI.conclusion: The method enhances threat analysis by providing SOC analysts with improved contextualization and insights through historical correlation, enabling more effective response to security alerts.

title: FusionMAE: large-scale pretrained model to optimize and simplify diagnostic and control of fusion plasma
summary:
In magnetically confined fusion device, the complex, multiscale, and
nonlinear dynamics of plasmas necessitate the integration of extensive
diagnostic systems to effectively monitor and control plasma behaviour. The
complexity and uncertainty arising from these extensive systems and their
tangled interrelations has long posed a significant obstacle to the
acceleration of fusion energy development. In this work, a large-scale model,
fusion masked auto-encoder (FusionMAE) is pre-trained to compress the
information from 88 diagnostic signals into a concrete embedding, to provide a
unified interface between diagnostic systems and control actuators. Two
mechanisms are proposed to ensure a meaningful embedding: compression-reduction
and missing-signal reconstruction. Upon completion of pre-training, the model
acquires the capability for 'virtual backup diagnosis', enabling the inference
of missing diagnostic data with 96.7% reliability. Furthermore, the model
demonstrates three emergent capabilities: automatic data analysis, universal
control-diagnosis interface, and enhancement of control performance on multiple
tasks. This work pioneers large-scale AI model integration in fusion energy,
demonstrating how pre-trained embeddings can simplify the system interface,
reducing necessary diagnostic systems and optimize operation performance for
future fusion reactors.

AI.tldr: The paper presents FusionMAE, a large-scale model leveraging AI to compress and unify diagnostic data in magnetically confined fusion devices. It enhances control and monitoring capabilities while reducing system complexity.
AI.motivation: Fusion energy development has been hindered by the complexity and uncertain interrelations among numerous diagnostic systems required for plasma monitoring. Integration and simplification of these systems are crucial for advancing fusion technology.
AI.method: The authors developed FusionMAE, an AI model pre-trained to process data from 88 diagnostic signals through compression-reduction and missing-signal reconstruction mechanisms. This ensures reliable embeddings for diagnostics and controls.
AI.result: FusionMAE achieves 'virtual backup diagnosis' to infer missing diagnostic data with 96.7% reliability. It also showcases emergent abilities: automatic data analysis, universal diagnostic-control interface, and improved control task performance.
AI.conclusion: The study introduces the potential for large-scale AI in evolving fusion energy systems by simplifying system interfaces and reducing diagnostic complexity, potentially accelerating fusion reactor operations.

title: xOffense: An AI-driven autonomous penetration testing framework with offensive knowledge-enhanced LLMs and multi agent systems
summary:
This work introduces xOffense, an AI-driven, multi-agent penetration testing
framework that shifts the process from labor-intensive, expert-driven manual
efforts to fully automated, machine-executable workflows capable of scaling
seamlessly with computational infrastructure. At its core, xOffense leverages a
fine-tuned, mid-scale open-source LLM (Qwen3-32B) to drive reasoning and
decision-making in penetration testing. The framework assigns specialized
agents to reconnaissance, vulnerability scanning, and exploitation, with an
orchestration layer ensuring seamless coordination across phases. Fine-tuning
on Chain-of-Thought penetration testing data further enables the model to
generate precise tool commands and perform consistent multi-step reasoning. We
evaluate xOffense on two rigorous benchmarks: AutoPenBench and
AI-Pentest-Benchmark. The results demonstrate that xOffense consistently
outperforms contemporary methods, achieving a sub-task completion rate of
79.17%, decisively surpassing leading systems such as VulnBot and PentestGPT.
These findings highlight the potential of domain-adapted mid-scale LLMs, when
embedded within structured multi-agent orchestration, to deliver superior,
cost-efficient, and reproducible solutions for autonomous penetration testing.

AI.tldr: The paper presents xOffense, a fully automated multi-agent penetration testing framework using an AI model for seamless, efficient cybersecurity assessments.
AI.motivation: To replace labor-intensive, expert-driven penetration testing with a scalable, automated AI-based approach.
AI.method: The framework uses a fine-tuned AI model (Qwen3-32B), organized into specialized agents for different testing tasks, with fine-tuning on Chain-of-Thought data for accurate reasoning and outputs.
AI.result: xOffense outperformed existing systems like VulnBot and PentestGPT, achieving a completion rate of 79.17% on specific benchmarks, showcasing its efficiency.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of using domain-adapted mid-scale LLMs in a structured multi-agent setup for automated cybersecurity testing.

title: Introducing the A2AJ's Canadian Legal Data: An open-source alternative to CanLII for the era of computational law
summary:
The Access to Algorithmic Justice project (A2AJ) is an open-source
alternative to the Canadian Legal Information Institute (CanLII). At a moment
when technology promises to enable new ways of working with law, CanLII is
becoming an impediment to the free access of law and access to justice
movements because it restricts bulk and programmatic access to Canadian legal
data. This means that Canada is staring down a digital divide: well-resourced
actors have the best new technological tools and, because CanLII has disclaimed
leadership, the public only gets second-rate tools. This article puts CanLII in
its larger historical context and shows how long and deep efforts to
democratize access to Canadian legal data are, and how often they are thwarted
by private industry. We introduce the A2AJ's Canadian Legal Data project, which
provides open access to over 116,000 court decisions and 5,000 statutes through
multiple channels including APIs, machine learning datasets, and AI integration
protocols. Through concrete examples, we demonstrate how open legal data
enables courts to conduct evidence-based assessments and allows developers to
create tools for practitioners serving low-income communities.

AI.tldr: The Access to Algorithmic Justice (A2AJ) project presents an open-source initiative for democratizing access to Canadian legal data through APIs, machine learning datasets, and AI protocols, contrasting with the restrictive access provided by CanLII.
AI.motivation: To address the inequity created by CanLII's limitations on bulk and programmatic access to Canadian legal data, which disproportionately benefits well-resourced actors while disadvantaging the broader public.
AI.method: Development of the A2AJ Canadian Legal Data project that provides open access to court decisions and statutes through APIs, machine learning datasets, and AI integration protocols.
AI.result: A database of 116,000+ court decisions and 5,000 statutes accessible via multiple technological formats, promoting broader accessibility and innovative legal applications.
AI.conclusion: Open legal data empowers equitable access to justice, facilitates evidence-based legal assessments, and fosters innovation for serving underserved communities.

title: Sublinear-Time Algorithms for Diagonally Dominant Systems and Applications to the Friedkin-Johnsen Model
summary:
We study sublinear-time algorithms for solving linear systems $Sz = b$, where
$S$ is a diagonally dominant matrix, i.e., $|S_{ii}| \geq \delta + \sum_{j \ne
i} |S_{ij}|$ for all $i \in [n]$, for some $\delta \geq 0$. We present
randomized algorithms that, for any $u \in [n]$, return an estimate $z_u$ of
$z^*_u$ with additive error $\varepsilon$ or $\varepsilon \lVert
z^*\rVert_\infty$, where $z^*$ is some solution to $Sz^* = b$, and the
algorithm only needs to read a small portion of the input $S$ and $b$. For
example, when the additive error is $\varepsilon$ and assuming $\delta>0$, we
give an algorithm that runs in time $O\left( \frac{\|b\|_\infty^2
S_{\max}}{\delta^3 \varepsilon^2} \log \frac{\| b \|_\infty}{\delta
\varepsilon} \right)$, where $S_{\max} = \max_{i \in [n]} |S_{ii}|$. We also
prove a matching lower bound, showing that the linear dependence on $S_{\max}$
is optimal. Unlike previous sublinear-time algorithms, which apply only to
symmetric diagonally dominant matrices with non-negative diagonal entries, our
algorithm works for general strictly diagonally dominant matrices ($\delta >
0$) and a broader class of non-strictly diagonally dominant matrices $(\delta =
0)$. Our approach is based on analyzing a simple probabilistic recurrence
satisfied by the solution. As an application, we obtain an improved
sublinear-time algorithm for opinion estimation in the Friedkin--Johnsen model.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces sublinear-time algorithms for estimating solutions to linear systems with diagonally dominant matrices, improving upon prior works by broadening the applicable matrix class and presenting enhanced performance bounds.
AI.motivation: Efficiently solving large linear systems is crucial due to their widespread application in scientific computing and modeling, yet evaluating specific parts of solutions in sublinear time remains a challenge.
AI.method: The method involves analyzing a probabilistic recurrence for solutions to linear systems and developing algorithms that provide additive error estimates while reading only a small portion of matrix and vector inputs.
AI.result: The algorithms achieve sublinear runtime bounds and support broader matrix classes (strictly and non-strictly diagonally dominant), with a proven optimal dependency on matrix parameters.
AI.conclusion: The approach generalizes prior methods to handle more matrices and achieves optimal runtime, opening up new applications like enhanced opinion estimation in social network models.

title: MIA-EPT: Membership Inference Attack via Error Prediction for Tabular Data
summary:
Synthetic data generation plays an important role in enabling data sharing,
particularly in sensitive domains like healthcare and finance. Recent advances
in diffusion models have made it possible to generate realistic, high-quality
tabular data, but they may also memorize training records and leak sensitive
information. Membership inference attacks (MIAs) exploit this vulnerability by
determining whether a record was used in training. While MIAs have been studied
in images and text, their use against tabular diffusion models remains
underexplored despite the unique risks of structured attributes and limited
record diversity. In this paper, we introduce MIAEPT, Membership Inference
Attack via Error Prediction for Tabular Data, a novel black-box attack
specifically designed to target tabular diffusion models. MIA-EPT constructs
errorbased feature vectors by masking and reconstructing attributes of target
records, disclosing membership signals based on how well these attributes are
predicted. MIA-EPT operates without access to the internal components of the
generative model, relying only on its synthetic data output, and was shown to
generalize across multiple state-of-the-art diffusion models. We validate
MIA-EPT on three diffusion-based synthesizers, achieving AUC-ROC scores of up
to 0.599 and TPR@10% FPR values of 22.0% in our internal tests. Under the MIDST
2025 competition conditions, MIA-EPT achieved second place in the Black-box
Multi-Table track (TPR@10% FPR = 20.0%). These results demonstrate that our
method can uncover substantial membership leakage in synthetic tabular data,
challenging the assumption that synthetic data is inherently
privacy-preserving. Our code is publicly available at
https://github.com/eyalgerman/MIA-EPT.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces MIA-EPT, a novel black-box attack targeting membership leakage in tabular diffusion models, achieving notable results in privacy vulnerability assessments.
AI.motivation: To address the vulnerability of diffusion models generating synthetic tabular data to membership inference attacks, which are underexplored despite significant privacy concerns.
AI.method: MIA-EPT creates error-based feature vectors using masked and reconstructed attributes, relying solely on the synthetic data output without accessing internal model components.
AI.result: MIA-EPT demonstrated effectiveness with AUC-ROC scores up to 0.599, and ranked second in the MIDST 2025 competition’s Black-box Multi-Table track.
AI.conclusion: Synthetic tabular data generated by diffusion models is not inherently privacy-preserving, as evidenced by substantial membership leakage uncovered by MIA-EPT.

title: Concentration inequalities for semidefinite least squares based on data
summary:
We study data-driven least squares (LS) problems with semidefinite (SD)
constraints and derive finite-sample guarantees on the spectrum of their
optimal solutions when these constraints are relaxed. In particular, we provide
a high confidence bound allowing one to solve a simpler program in place of the
full SDLS problem, while ensuring that the eigenvalues of the resulting
solution are $\varepsilon$-close of those enforced by the SD constraints. The
developed certificate, which consistently shrinks as the number of data
increases, turns out to be easy-to-compute, distribution-free, and only
requires independent and identically distributed samples. Moreover, when the
SDLS is used to learn an unknown quadratic function, we establish bounds on the
error between a gradient descent iterate minimizing the surrogate cost obtained
with no SD constraints and the true minimizer.

AI.tldr: This study examines least squares problems with semidefinite constraints, offering guarantees that enable simplified computations while maintaining eigenvalue accuracy.
AI.motivation: Least squares problems with semidefinite constraints are computationally intensive, but their simplifications can provide valuable insights without losing spectrum fidelity.
AI.method: The authors derive finite-sample guarantees for relaxed semidefinite constraints and provide error bounds for approximating solutions, requiring independent, identically distributed samples.
AI.result: They produce high-confidence bounds that narrow as data samples increase, and establish guarantees on error approximations for gradient descent solutions without semidefinite constraints.
AI.conclusion: The findings allow practitioners to efficiently approximate solutions to semidefinite least squares problems, with robust error certificates for eigenvalue proximities and gradient descent methods.

title: Efficient Cold-Start Recommendation via BPE Token-Level Embedding Initialization with LLM
summary:
The cold-start issue is the challenge when we talk about recommender systems,
especially in the case when we do not have the past interaction data of new
users or new items. Content-based features or hybrid solutions are common as
conventional solutions, but they can only work in a sparse metadata environment
with shallow patterns. In this paper, the efficient cold-start recommendation
strategy is presented, which is based on the sub word-level representations by
applying Byte Pair Encoding (BPE) tokenization and pre-trained Large Language
Model (LLM) embedding in the initialization procedure. We obtain fine-grained
token-level vectors that are aligned with the BPE vocabulary as opposed to
using coarse-grained sentence embeddings. Together, these token embeddings can
be used as dense semantic priors on unseen entities, making immediate
recommendation performance possible without user-item interaction history. Our
mechanism can be compared to collaborative filtering systems and tested over
benchmark datasets with stringent cold-start assumptions. Experimental findings
show that the given BPE-LLM method achieves higher Recall@k, NDCG@k, and Hit
Rate measurements compared to the standard baseline and displays the same
capability of sufficient computational performance. Furthermore, we demonstrate
that using subword-aware embeddings yields better generalizability and is more
interpretable, especially within a multilingual and sparse input setting. The
practical application of token-level semantic initialization as a lightweight,
but nevertheless effective extension to modern recommender systems in the
zero-shot setting is indicated within this work.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses the cold-start issue in recommender systems by creating a novel strategy using subword-level representations derived from Byte Pair Encoding (BPE) and pre-trained Large Language Models (LLMs).
AI.motivation: The cold-start challenge presents difficulties in recommending items or services for new users or items without prior interaction data. Conventional methods often struggle in sparse metadata environments and fail to capture deeper semantic patterns.
AI.method: The authors propose a novel approach utilizing BPE tokenization and pre-trained LLM embeddings at the token level, to provide detailed and fine-grained semantic representations for unseen entities, enabling recommendations without prior interaction history.
AI.result: Experimental evaluations demonstrate that the BPE-LLM approach outperforms baseline recommender system methods, achieving higher Recall@k, NDCG@k, and Hit Rate metrics on benchmark datasets, while maintaining computational efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Token-level semantic initialization using subword-aware embeddings offers a robust, generalizable, and interpretable approach, effectively addressing cold-start problems in multilingual and sparse input scenarios, and serves as a lightweight extension for modern recommender systems in zero-shot contexts.

title: Flow-Based Fragment Identification via Binding Site-Specific Latent Representations
summary:
Fragment-based drug design is a promising strategy leveraging the binding of
small chemical moieties that can efficiently guide drug discovery. The initial
step of fragment identification remains challenging, as fragments often bind
weakly and non-specifically. We developed a protein-fragment encoder that
relies on a contrastive learning approach to map both molecular fragments and
protein surfaces in a shared latent space. The encoder captures
interaction-relevant features and allows to perform virtual screening as well
as generative design with our new method LatentFrag. In LatentFrag, fragment
embeddings and positions are generated conditioned on the protein surface while
being chemically realistic by construction. Our expressive fragment and protein
representations allow location of protein-fragment interaction sites with high
sensitivity and we observe state-of-the-art fragment recovery rates when
sampling from the learned distribution of latent fragment embeddings. Our
generative method outperforms common methods such as virtual screening at a
fraction of its computational cost providing a valuable starting point for
fragment hit discovery. We further show the practical utility of LatentFrag and
extend the workflow to full ligand design tasks. Together, these approaches
contribute to advancing fragment identification and provide valuable tools for
fragment-based drug discovery.

AI.tldr: The research introduces LatentFrag, a solution for fragment-based drug design utilizing contrastive learning to encode protein-fragment interactions effectively, enabling sensitive predictions and superior generative drug design.
AI.motivation: Fragment-based drug design faces challenges in the weak and non-specific binding of fragments, necessitating methods for more efficient fragment identification and guided discovery.
AI.method: The study developed a protein-fragment encoder based on contrastive learning, mapping fragments and protein surfaces in a shared latent space, and introduced LatentFrag for virtual screening and generative fragment design conditioned on protein surfaces.
AI.result: LatentFrag demonstrated high sensitivity in locating protein-fragment interaction sites, achieved state-of-the-art fragment recovery rates, and provided superior outcomes compared to traditional virtual screening methods at lower computational cost.
AI.conclusion: LatentFrag advances fragment identification, streamlines generative drug design, and offers effective tools for fragment-driven drug discovery, paving the way for more efficient and practical workflows in ligand design.

title: Accelerating Protein Molecular Dynamics Simulation with DeepJump
summary:
Unraveling the dynamical motions of biomolecules is essential for bridging
their structure and function, yet it remains a major computational challenge.
Molecular dynamics (MD) simulation provides a detailed depiction of
biomolecular motion, but its high-resolution temporal evolution comes at
significant computational cost, limiting its applicability to timescales of
biological relevance. Deep learning approaches have emerged as promising
solutions to overcome these computational limitations by learning to predict
long-timescale dynamics. However, generalizable kinetics models for proteins
remain largely unexplored, and the fundamental limits of achievable
acceleration while preserving dynamical accuracy are poorly understood. In this
work, we fill this gap with DeepJump, an Euclidean-Equivariant Flow
Matching-based model for predicting protein conformational dynamics across
multiple temporal scales. We train DeepJump on trajectories of the diverse
proteins of mdCATH, systematically studying our model's performance in
generalizing to long-term dynamics of fast-folding proteins and characterizing
the trade-off between computational acceleration and prediction accuracy. We
demonstrate the application of DeepJump to ab initio folding, showcasing
prediction of folding pathways and native states. Our results demonstrate that
DeepJump achieves significant $\approx$1000$\times$ computational acceleration
while effectively recovering long-timescale dynamics, providing a stepping
stone for enabling routine simulation of proteins.

AI.tldr: DeepJump, a deep learning model, accelerates protein dynamics simulations by approximately 1000 times while maintaining long-timescale accuracy.
AI.motivation: The study aims to overcome computational constraints in molecular dynamics simulations, which limit the study of biomolecular motions on biologically relevant timescales.
AI.method: The authors developed DeepJump, an Euclidean-Equivariant Flow Matching-based model, and trained it on diverse protein trajectories to predict long-term dynamics and analyze computational trade-offs.
AI.result:
DeepJump can predict folding pathways, native states, and long-timescale dynamics of proteins, achieving a computational speed-up of $
approx 1000\times$.
AI.conclusion: DeepJump enables significantly faster and accurate simulation of protein dynamics, thus advancing the routine study of biomolecular motions.

title: Rich Vehicle Routing Problem with diverse Vertices allowing Hierarchical and Multimodal Time-Dependant Transhipment of multiple Node- Vehicle- compatible Cargo with Cascaded Time-Minimization Objective for Emergency Decision Support Systems
summary:
A rich vehicle routing problem is considered allowing multiple trips of
heterogeneous vehicles stationed at distributed vehicle depots spread across
diverse geographies having access to different modes of transportation. The
problem arises from the real world requirement of optimizing the disaster
response/preparedness time and minimizes the route duration of the vehicles to
achieve the solution with the minimum highest-vehicle-route-duration. Multiple
diversely-functional vertices are considered including the concept of
Transhipment Ports as inter-modal resource transfer stations. Both simultaneous
and split pickup and transferring of different types of delivery and pickup
cargo is considered, along with Vehicle-Cargo and Transhipment Port-Cargo
Compatibility. The superiority of the proposed cascaded minimization approach
is shown over existing makespan minimization approaches through the developed
MILP formulation. To solve the problem quickly for practical implementation
within Disaster Management-specific Decision Support Systems, an extensive
Heuristic Algorithm is devised. The Heuristic utilizes Decision Tree based
structuring of possible routes and is able to inherently consider the
compatibility issues. Preferential generation of small route elements are
performed, which are integrated into route clusters; we consider multiple
different logical integration approaches, as well as shuffling the logics to
simultaneously produce multiple independent solutions. Finally perturbation of
the different solutions are done to find better neighbouring solutions. The
computational performance of the PSR-GIP Heuristic, on our created novel
datasets, indicate that it is able to give good solutions swiftly for practical
problems involving large integer instances which the MILP is unable to solve.

AI.tldr: This study tackles an advanced vehicle routing issue for disaster management involving multiple depots, heterogeneous vehicles, and diverse transportation modes. A heuristic algorithm is developed for practical implementation, surpassing existing methods.
AI.motivation: Optimize disaster management logistics to minimize route duration and improve preparedness and response times.
AI.method: Developed a heuristic algorithm called PSR-GIP that utilizes decision trees and route clustering strategies, combined with perturbation techniques.
AI.result: The PSR-GIP heuristic demonstrated effective and swift solutions for large-scale practical problems on novel datasets.
AI.conclusion: The heuristic outperforms MILP formulations, proving its suitability for real-world disaster response decision systems.

title: Layout-Aware OCR for Black Digital Archives with Unsupervised Evaluation
summary:
Despite their cultural and historical significance, Black digital archives
continue to be a structurally underrepresented area in AI research and
infrastructure. This is especially evident in efforts to digitize historical
Black newspapers, where inconsistent typography, visual degradation, and
limited annotated layout data hinder accurate transcription, despite the
availability of various systems that claim to handle optical character
recognition (OCR) well. In this short paper, we present a layout-aware OCR
pipeline tailored for Black newspaper archives and introduce an unsupervised
evaluation framework suited to low-resource archival contexts. Our approach
integrates synthetic layout generation, model pretraining on augmented data,
and a fusion of state-of-the-art You Only Look Once (YOLO) detectors. We used
three annotation-free evaluation metrics, the Semantic Coherence Score (SCS),
Region Entropy (RE), and Textual Redundancy Score (TRS), which quantify
linguistic fluency, informational diversity, and redundancy across OCR regions.
Our evaluation on a 400-page dataset from ten Black newspaper titles
demonstrates that layout-aware OCR improves structural diversity and reduces
redundancy compared to full-page baselines, with modest trade-offs in
coherence. Our results highlight the importance of respecting cultural layout
logic in AI-driven document understanding and lay the foundation for future
community-driven and ethically grounded archival AI systems.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses the challenges of applying Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to historical Black newspapers and proposes a layout-aware OCR pipeline specialized for this context.
AI.motivation: To address the structural underrepresentation of Black digital archives in AI research, particularly in OCR applications for historical Black newspapers.
AI.method: The authors utilized synthetic layout generation, pretraining on augmented datasets, and YOLO detector fusion along with annotation-free metrics like Semantic Coherence Score (SCS), Region Entropy (RE), and Textual Redundancy Score (TRS) for evaluation.
AI.result: Experiments on a dataset of 400 pages from ten historical Black newspaper titles showed improvements in structural diversity and reduced redundancy compared to full-page baselines, albeit with slight coherence trade-offs.
AI.conclusion: The study emphasizes the significance of honoring cultural layout contexts in AI-driven document analysis, advocating for future community-oriented, ethical AI systems for archival purposes.

title: Contrastive timbre representations for musical instrument and synthesizer retrieval
summary:
Efficiently retrieving specific instrument timbres from audio mixtures
remains a challenge in digital music production. This paper introduces a
contrastive learning framework for musical instrument retrieval, enabling
direct querying of instrument databases using a single model for both single-
and multi-instrument sounds. We propose techniques to generate realistic
positive/negative pairs of sounds for virtual musical instruments, such as
samplers and synthesizers, addressing limitations in common audio data
augmentation methods.
  The first experiment focuses on instrument retrieval from a dataset of 3,884
instruments, using single-instrument audio as input. Contrastive approaches are
competitive with previous works based on classification pre-training. The
second experiment considers multi-instrument retrieval with a mixture of
instruments as audio input. In this case, the proposed contrastive framework
outperforms related works, achieving 81.7\% top-1 and 95.7\% top-5 accuracies
for three-instrument mixtures.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a contrastive learning framework for musical instrument retrieval using both single and multi-instrument sounds.
AI.motivation: The challenge of efficiently retrieving specific instrument timbres from audio mixtures in digital music production.
AI.method: Contrastive learning framework with novel data augmentation techniques to generate positive/negative sound pairs for virtual musical instruments.
AI.result: Contrastive approaches achieve competitive performance for single-instrument retrieval and outperform existing methods for multi-instrument retrieval, with high top-1 and top-5 accuracies.
AI.conclusion: The framework effectively addresses limitations in audio data augmentation, enhancing instrument retrieval tasks in both single and multi-instrument contexts.
